title: Make WPF open-source and accept pull-requests from the community
body: Please follow the footsteps of the ASP .NET team and make WPF open-source with the source code on GitHub, and accept pull-requests from the community.

comments.body:
They did it: https://github.com/dotnet/wpf
hooray!!

@Bogdan: Have a look at https://github.com/AvaloniaUI/Avalonia

I don't know if WPF will ever become open source... but I would love for a similar framework to be created for the cross-platform development.  There are some out there, but they leave a lot to be desired for.  I've been developing in WPF for the past three and a half years and it is pure joy.  I am absolutely in love with the framework.

Well, except for the native part, it already is kind of open source (via the .NET Reference Source), but it would still help the platform if all of it was available in the open. Long standing bugs could be fixed by the community, and the framework itself customized and packaged by third-parties on a per-app basis (I guess there are already plans for something like that with WPF app local).
The Great idea
@Zagor Tenay
Absolutely. Please make it open source. Go for it.

In the last few years, there has been a shift from the backend to the frontend. Shifting the business logic of web apps from the backend to the frontend, with the backend being delegated to a simple API. This makes the choice of a frontend framework that much more important.

Especially with what's going on cross platform developments at MS (i.e.xamarin), I think it is a good idea.
Why .net core and other technologies alredy open source while old WPF is still not?
Does Microsoft actually read any of the community posts?
My god, imagine the sheer number of useful controls we could have!!  All the stuff that I usually have to get from the WPF Toolkit or Extended WPF Toolkit!
Some reasons to do so here http://forums.dotnetfoundation.org/t/cross-platform-wpf/421
usman
Any intermediate solution by the way would be just to open the graphics and input level interfaces and allow the  community to write plugins for other environments.
WPF is really what C# needs to become a full cross platform client solution.  With .NET core now open source, this is a logical next step.
I agree with Cyral, C# and WPF are an amazing Framework.  Opening it up to the community will help foster cross platform development and will strengthen Windows Store offerings.

WPF is an amazing framework, making it open source would allow it to see more features and fixes from the community. I'm sure it wouldn't be long before a team such as Mono ports it to other platforms.
